docs.abstract: China's universities produced more than six million graduates last May, but even China's robust economy does not generate enough good professional jobs to absorb them; young people find themselves working for poor wages and are known as 'ant tribe' for their dense settlements in crowded neighborhoods; situation is raising concerns within government fixated on stability; photo (M)

headline.main: China's Army Of Graduates Is Struggling

docs.snippet: Villagers who will work in China’s factories are in demand, but many college graduates seeking professional jobs find their value plunging.

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS; Xiyun Yang and Benjamin Haas contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- Liu Yang, a coal miner's daughter, arrived in the capital this past summer with a freshly printed diploma from Datong University, $140 in her wallet and an air of invincibility. Her first taste of reality came later the same day, as she lugged her bags through a ramshackle neighborhood, not far from the Olympic Village, where tens of thousands of other young strivers cram four to a room.

headline.main: Boom Times for Opera in China

docs.snippet: New opera productions abound in China, and many are being adapted or created for the local audience with an eye to going global.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- On the frosty first Saturday of December, crowds packed the opera house of the National Center for the Performing Arts in Beijing to see ''Xi Shi,'' an original NCPA production (composed by Lei Lei with libretto by Zou Jingzhi) that tells the tragic tale of the eponymous beauty from ancient China. When it had its premiere in April, the opera was hailed by some here as evidence of China becoming a great cultural power.

docs.abstract: Beijing Journal: Beijing's plan to tackle suffocating city traffic includes new parking spaces, new downtown streets, new transportation hubs, and congestion zones, but many believe it is an exercise in futility; as of December, Beijing counted 4.7 million registered vehicles, with 2,000 new ones joining the fray each day; photo (M)

headline.main: Cars Multiply, But Chinese Still Can't Find A Fast Lane

docs.snippet: In the latest match between Beijing’s build-baby-build bureaucrats and its Gordian knot of traffic, more than a few folks are betting on the knot.

byline.original: By MICHAEL WINES; Zhang Jing, Benjamin Haas and Li Bibo contributed research, and Jonathan Ansfield contributed reporting

docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- Here is the plan unwrapped last week by Beijing's city fathers to tackle the city's suffocating traffic: 280,000 new parking spaces; 1,000 share-a-bike stations; 348 miles of new subway track; 125 miles of new downtown streets; 23 miles of tunnels; 9 new transportation hubs; 3 congestion zones; and 1 cure-all, ''the use of modern technology.''

headline.main: Plan to Ease Beijing Traffic Hits a Bump

docs.snippet: A record splurge on new-car purchases by Beijingers, who apparently anticipated that the city was about to tackle its traffic jams by limiting registrations of new vehicles.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- In Beijing's newfound enthusiasm to address its smothering traffic jams, it appears that Huang Wei has succeeded too well. Mr. Huang, Beijing's vice mayor for traffic management, resigned Thursday and was reassigned to remote western China, the exile destination of choice for those out of favor. The demotion followed a record splurge on new-car purchases by Beijingers, who apparently anticipated that the city was about to tackle its traffic jams by limiting registrations of new vehicles.

keywords.name: glocations
keywords.value: FAR EAST, SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ASIA AND PACIFIC AREAS

docs.snippet: The state-run “patriotic” Catholic Church and the Vatican are warring over the consciences of believers.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- A strangely compelling mix of Italian Baroque and traditional Chinese music swirled inside South Cathedral on a recent Sunday evening, as the early music ensemble Sacabuche and Beijing musicians performed an artistic tribute to the Jesuit priest Matteo Ricci, who died 400 years ago in this city. The merging and sparring of 15th-century trombone and violin with the ancient stringed zheng and piped sheng, heard most powerfully in the finale by the New York-based composer Huang Ruo, seemed to mirror the turmoil within the Catholic Church this Christmas.
